G.L. c. 208, \u0000\u0000\u0000\u0000\u0.proposition: This Complaint is brought pursuant to G.L. c. 208, ����������������������������������������������������������������������������������� which governs changes in custody and recognizes that a material and substantial change in circumstances justifies modification when it serves the childs best interests.

Custody of Zia, 50 Mass. App. Ct. 237, 2.raw_text: Custody of Zia, 50 Mass. App. Ct. 237, 239 (2000)
Custody of Zia, 50 Mass. App. Ct. 237, 2.proposition: The defining principle underlying child custody arrangements in Massachusetts is to ensure the best interests of the child.
Custody of Zia, 50 Mass. App. Ct. 237, 2.support_reasoning: The opinion expressly states that custody orders and judgments under G.L. c. 209C are made on the basis of determining the best interests of the child, and repeatedly frames the judge’s decision in those terms. It treats the best-interests standard as the governing principle for custody determinations in Massachusetts, aligning with the claimed proposition about the defining principle underlying custody arrangements.
Custody of Zia, 50 Mass. App. Ct. 237, 2.relevant_excerpt: “‘[C]ustody orders and judgments [including those under G. L. c. 209C] are made on the basis of a determination of the best interests of the child . . . .’ R. H. v. B. F., 39 Mass. App. Ct. at 39. … and a judge may consider any factors found pertinent to those interests in the circumstances of the dispute.”

Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834, 839 (200.proposition: The defining principle underlying child custody arrangements in Massachusetts is to ensure the best interests of the child.
Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834, 839 (200.support_reasoning: The opinion squarely discusses the governing standard for custody determinations in Massachusetts and traces the ‘best interests of the child’ standard as the controlling principle in custody cases. It explains that G.L. c. 209C, § 10(a) authorizes custody awards “as may be appropriate in the best interests of the child” and describes that standard as the longstanding and paramount concern in Massachusetts custody law, thus supporting the proposition that ensuring the child’s best interests is the defining principle underlying custody arrangements.
Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834, 839 (200.relevant_excerpt: “Section 10 (a) gives a probate judge the power to award custody of nonmarital children ‘to the mother or the father or to them jointly ... as may be appropriate in the best interests of the child.’ … The ‘best interests’ standard appeared in our case law at least as early as 1865… It has been adhered to ever since. See, e.g., Blixt v. Blixt… (best interests standard ‘has long been used in Massachusetts to decide issues of custody and visitation’); Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas… (‘best interests of the children always remain the paramount concern’).”}

Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 7.proposition: In determining custody modifications, courts consider the totality of the circumstances, which may include changes in parental circumstances, the childs mental and emotional well-being, and the importance of continued and meaningful relationships with both parents.
Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 7.support_reasoning: The case expressly describes the custody/removal determination as a best-interests, totality-of-the-circumstances inquiry, listing multiple factors. The court instructs judges to consider how the move affects the child’s quality of life (including the custodial parent’s circumstances), the child’s emotional, physical, and developmental needs, and the adverse effect of curtailing association with the noncustodial parent, which encompasses the child’s mental/emotional well-being and the value of continued relationships with both parents. This aligns with the proposition’s description of the analysis for custody-related modifications.
Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 7.relevant_excerpt: “Cases involving removal of a child from the jurisdiction present difficult choices. Unless one is to apply a fixed but arbitrary rule, the issue can be resolved only on a case by case basis. The effect on the child of any removal is most important. An evaluation of the best interests of the child requires attention to whether the quality of the child’s life may be improved by the change (including any improvement flowing from an improvement in the quality of the custodial parent’s life), the possible adverse effect of the elimination or curtailment of the child’s association with the noncustodial parent, and the extent to which moving or not moving will affect the emotional, physical, or developmental needs of the child.”

Adoption of Hugo, 428 Mass. 219, 228 (19.proposition: In determining custody modifications, courts consider the totality of the circumstances, which may include changes in parental circumstances, the childs mental and emotional well-being, and the importance of continued and meaningful relationships with both parents.
Adoption of Hugo, 428 Mass. 219, 228 (19.support_reasoning: The case is an adoption/care-and-protection decision, not a post-divorce custody-modification case, and it does not frame the inquiry as a custody modification standard. While the court does discuss the child’s best interests and weighs stability, developmental and emotional needs, and family relationships, it does so under G.L. c. 210, § 3 in choosing between competing adoptive placements, not in the context of modifying custody between parents. Thus it is not accurate authority for a general rule about ‘custody modifications’ as described in the proposition.
Adoption of Hugo, 428 Mass. 219, 228 (19.relevant_excerpt: Once the judge concluded that parental unfitness was established, he correctly determined that the central question was whether it was in Hugo’s best interests to remain with his foster mother or to be transferred to the care and custody of his aunt. G. L. c. 210, § 3 (c). … Here, the judge had to weigh the benefits of stability, of keeping Hugo in his present home, with moving him to a family where, in his judgment, it is more likely that Hugo will receive the home support, stability, and reinforcement of efforts to address his developmental needs so critical to his future development.

Guardianship of Minor, 42 Mass. App. Ct..raw_text: Guardianship of Minor, 42 Mass. App. Ct. 427, 434 (1997)
Guardianship of Minor, 42 Mass. App. Ct..proposition: The Court has also recognized the relevance of a childs expressed preferences, especially when supported by expert testimony demonstrating emotional distress under the current custody arrangement.
Guardianship of Minor, 42 Mass. App. Ct..case_name: Covell v. Department of Social Services
Guardianship of Minor, 42 Mass. App. Ct..support_reasoning: This opinion concerns administrative and procedural issues surrounding DSS registry proceedings, timeliness of judicial review under G.L. c. 30A, and an agency’s power to reopen proceedings. It does not involve a guardianship or custody dispute, does not discuss a child’s expressed custodial preferences, and does not reference expert testimony about a child’s emotional distress under a custody arrangement. Therefore it cannot be cited as authority for the proposition stated.
Guardianship of Minor, 42 Mass. App. Ct..relevant_excerpt: The case of Aronson v. Brookline Rent Control Bd., 19 Mass. App. Ct. 700, 703-706 (1985), teaches that agencies have inherent power to reopen their concluded proceedings in compelling situations as justice may require. Aronson was a case where the agency acted to consider an allegation that a party had committed a fraud affecting the earlier agency decision, but Aronson acknowledges, as do later cases, that other kinds of claims might rightly impel an agency to allow reopening.

Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398, 4.raw_text: Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398, 404 (1981)
Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398, 4.proposition: The Court has also recognized the relevance of a childs expressed preferences, especially when supported by expert testimony demonstrating emotional distress under the current custody arrangement.
Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398, 4.support_reasoning: The opinion discusses the best interests standard, parental conflict, joint vs. sole custody, and relies heavily on expert testimony and reports, but it does not mention or analyze the children’s own expressed custodial preferences or their wishes regarding living arrangements. Nor does it tie any expert testimony specifically to the children’s expressed desires or emotional distress with the current custody arrangement. Therefore, it cannot be cited as authority for the proposition that the court recognized the relevance of a child’s expressed preferences supported by expert testimony of emotional distress.
Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398, 4.relevant_excerpt: “The judge had the benefit of testimony from expert witnesses, reports from experts, and proposed findings from a court appointed counsel representing the children and their separate interests. The judge concluded that ‘joint custody or shared responsibility is an invitation to continued warfare and conflict.’ The judge found the wife has been the ‘primary nurturing parent’ and ‘primary caretaker’ and that the children have the ‘strongest bond’ with their mother.”

Woodside v. Woodside, 79 Mass. App. Ct..raw_text: Woodside v. Woodside, 79 Mass. App. Ct. 713, 719 (2011)
Woodside v. Woodside, 79 Mass. App. Ct..proposition: Moreover, judges in Massachusetts are encouraged to adopt custody orders that reflect a favorable balance between the rights of both parents and the long-term best interests of the child.
Woodside v. Woodside, 79 Mass. App. Ct..support_reasoning: The opinion discusses the standard for removal of children from the Commonwealth and explains that the statute balances the rights of the noncustodial parent and child with the custodial parent’s right to seek a better life, but it does not articulate any broad, affirmative encouragement to adopt custody orders that reflect a ‘favorable balance’ between both parents’ rights and the child’s long‑term best interests. Its focus is on which removal test applies (Yannas vs. Mason/Wakefield) and on the best‑interests analysis in that context, not on general guidance about crafting custody orders. The proposition overstates and generalizes what the case actually says.
Woodside v. Woodside, 79 Mass. App. Ct..relevant_excerpt: “The statute is intended to ‘preserve the rights of the noncustodial parent and the child to maintain and develop their familiar relationships, while balancing those rights with the right of the custodial parent to seek a better life for himself or herself.’ … The primary consideration in both tests remains whether the proposed move is in the best interests of the child.”

Maldonado v. Maldonado, 55 Mass. App. Ct.raw_text: Maldonado v. Maldonado, 55 Mass. App. Ct. 607, 611 (2002)
Maldonado v. Maldonado, 55 Mass. App. Ct.proposition: Moreover, judges in Massachusetts are encouraged to adopt custody orders that reflect a favorable balance between the rights of both parents and the long-term best interests of the child.
Maldonado v. Maldonado, 55 Mass. App. Ct.support_reasoning: The case concerns whether certain parcels of real estate were partnership property and how they should be treated upon a partner’s death. It does not address child custody, parental rights, or any family-law best-interests analysis. Therefore, it cannot be cited as authority for a proposition about Massachusetts judges being encouraged to adopt custody orders balancing parental rights and children’s long-term best interests.
Maldonado v. Maldonado, 55 Mass. App. Ct.relevant_excerpt: The death of a partner causes the dissolution of the partnership in the absence of an agreement otherwise. G. L. c. 108A, § 31(4). On dissolution, the partnership “continues until the winding up of partnership affairs is completed.” G. L. c. 108A, § 30. “On the death of a partner his right in specific partnership property vests in the surviving partner . . . [who] has no right to possess the partnership property for any but a partnership purpose.” G. L. c. 108A, § 25(2)(d).

Smith v. McDonald, 458 Mass. 540, 549 (2.proposition: In evaluating modifications, courts have repeatedly emphasized the importance of parental cooperation and open communication.
Smith v. McDonald, 458 Mass. 540, 549 (2.support_reasoning: The concurrence is focused on statutory interpretation of the paternity statute, relocation when there is only one legal parent, and the limits of a judge’s authority to order a custodial parent to return to Massachusetts. It does not discuss, much less emphasize, parental cooperation or open communication as factors in modification or custody decisions. Therefore, this case does not provide authority for the claimed proposition.
Smith v. McDonald, 458 Mass. 540, 549 (2.relevant_excerpt: After paternity was established, the judge was obligated to take as a given that the mother and the child resided 400 miles apart from, and in another State than, the father, and to fashion custody and visitation orders pursuant to the three factors set out in G. L. c. 209C, § 10 (a), again respecting and not disturbing the mother’s decision to relocate.
